awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Biomimetic and Soft Robotics (BioSoRo): from Biological Inspirations to Engineered Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
This Biomimetic and Soft Robotics (BioSoRo) REU Site at the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR) will engage a diverse cohort of undergraduate students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. Hosted by the departments of Mechanical Engineering, Electrical & Biomedical Engineering, and Biology at UNR, this program focuses on multidisciplinary collaborative projects related to BioSoRo research that span the fields of biomimetics, additive manufacturing, smart materials, solid mechanics, and robotics and control. Participants work closely with graduate student and faculty mentors on their respective research projects, gain the knowledge and tools for progression in STEM, build a community of professionals with peers, graduate students, and faculty, and grow in their perspective on the role of STEM in society. In addition to ten weeks of intensive research, students take part in educational, social, and professional development activities that support their sustained growth as engineers and scientists, including workshops on career development, scholarship community colloquiums, and tours to Tesla Gigafactory and Amazon Warehouse where industrial robots are massively adopted. 

Research projects at this BioSoRo REU site entail crawling legless animals and soft crawling robots inspired by them, electroactive polymers and their applications in soft robots, supercoiled polymer actuators for soft robots, and smart materials enabled compliant biomedical devices, among others. These projects will offer an advanced and interdisciplinary platform for enhancing undergraduate research experience in the cutting-edge BioSoRo research area, which perfectly leverages fundamental science with state-of-the-art engineering. This REU Site will capitalize on the broad appeal of BioSoRo research to increase the diversity and broaden the horizons of students engaged in robotics research. Students with experience in BioSoRo are in great demand and this REU site will help train and diversify the next generation of roboticists in the 21st century.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Biomimetic and Soft Robotics (BioSoRo) REU site has two primary goals. First, we aim to train students in the development and evaluation of biomimetic and soft robots, utilizing innovative actuators and control mechanisms that enable navigation through natural environments with flexibility and a high degree of freedom. Second, we seek to leverage the broad appeal of BioSoRo research to enhance diversity and broaden the perspectives of students in robotics. By achieving these goals, we aim to significantly expand and diversify the pipeline of graduate students in bioinspired robotics research. Given the growing demand for expertise in BioSoRo, this project is essential for training and diversifying the next generation of roboticists for the 21st century.

The REU site operates 7-8 projects annually, each led by 7-8 faculty members from various disciplines, with the goal of training 14 students per year. Since its inception in 2019, the program has successfully conducted four sessions, training 14 students in 2019, 17 in 2021, 16 in 2022, and 5 in 2023. The program was extended for two additional years to address disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Over the past five years, REU projects have focused on multidisciplinary, collaborative efforts related to BioSoRo research, spanning fields such as biomimetics, additive manufacturing, smart materials, solid mechanics, robotics, and control systems. Students develop technical skills in areas including biomimetic smart materials design, bio-inspired dynamic friction manipulation, the mechanics of bio-inspired reinforced thin wire buckling, the design and fabrication of bio-inspired robotic medical devices, artificial muscle design, actuation strategies, computational modeling, biomechanics of natural locomotion, and active sensation feedback mechanisms. Each REU student receives training and mentorship from graduate students and faculty members across the Mechanical Engineering, Electrical & Biomedical Engineering, and Biology Departments, as well as the Institute of Neuroscience.

Following the site’s implementation, we have successfully achieved several significant outcomes or findings:

Intellectual Merit: The REU site offers an advanced, interdisciplinary platform that enhances undergraduate research experiences in cutting-edge BioSoRo technology. It trains students in the development and evaluation of biomimetic and soft robots, incorporating novel sensors, actuators, and engineered mechanisms inspired by biological systems. The interdisciplinary nature of this field allows students to gain knowledge across multiple domains, including solid mechanics, materials engineering, electrical engineering, biomedical engineering, biology, and neuroscience.

Broader Impacts and Significant Outcomes: To date, the REU site has trained 50 students from 15 universities nationwide, including 17 female and 33 male students, with 44% being underrepresented minorities and/or female. These students have presented their research at the UNR Undergraduate Research Symposium, Innovation Day, and various national and international conferences. Approximately 42% of participating REU students have applied or were applying to graduate schools. The project has resulted in 11 publications, including 6 journal articles and 5 conference papers; 1 patent application; over 20 research reports, abstracts, and slides; around 30 research posters; and numerous hands-on hardware and software prototypes in labs. Evaluations indicate that over 87.5% of REU students were highly satisfied with the program. The insights and outcomes from this site will inform and enhance the implementation of future REU activities, both within our program and in others.


Last Modified: 08/25/2024
Modified by: Yantao Shen
